skill.name: ghe-claim
skill.description:
CLAIM a specific GitHub issue to START working on it. Requires an issue number. Performs validation, atomic claim, posts claim comment, and sets up worktree.

USE WHEN: User wants to begin work on a specific issue (e.g., "claim issue #N", "start working on #N").

REQUIRED: Issue number must be specified.

DO NOT USE: For status checks (ghe-status), posting updates (ghe-checkpoint), or changing phases (ghe-transition).

security_audit.summary: The ghe-claim skill contains NO executable code - it's purely documentation and instruction prompts for Claude on how to use GitHub's API for issue management. All 25 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The static analyzer misinterpreted JSON metadata fields, workflow documentation references, and standard configuration paths as security threats when they are benign documentation elements.

content.user_title: Claim GitHub Issues to Start Development Work
content.value_statement: Starting work on GitHub issues requires manual assignment and setup. This skill automates the entire claim process with validation, atomic assignment, and worktree creation.
actual_capabilities: Atomically assigns issues to prevent conflicts
Posts standardized claim comments to GitHub
Automatically creates git worktrees for development
Integrates with GHE phase-based workflow system
Updates SERENA memory bank with claim events
limitations: Requires specific issue number in conversation

use_cases.title: Start New Development Tasks
use_cases.description: Claim ready-to-work GitHub issues and automatically set up development environment with proper phase tracking.

use_cases.title: Assign Work Transparently
use_cases.description: Ensure atomic issue assignment with full audit trail and prevent duplicate work across team members.

use_cases.title: Pick Up Available Issues
use_cases.description: Quickly claim good-first-issues or help-wanted items with automatic setup and community notification.

best_practices: Always claim issues before starting work to prevent conflicts
Use specific issue numbers to avoid ambiguity
Check issue labels match your intended phase (dev/test/review)
anti_patterns: Don't start work without claiming - causes duplicate effort
Avoid claiming multiple issues simultaneously without coordination
Never claim issues already assigned to others

faq.question: What happens if someone else claims the issue first?
faq.answer: The skill performs atomic assignment - if another user claims first, you'll get an error preventing duplicate assignment.

faq.question: Can I claim issues in any phase?
faq.answer: The skill validates phase order - issues must progress through DEV then TEST then REVIEW sequentially.

faq.question: Does this work with private repositories?
faq.answer: Yes, as long as you have proper GitHub permissions and GHE is configured for the repository.

faq.question: What if I need to abandon an issue?
faq.answer: Use ghe-transition to properly release the issue and update its status for others to pick up.

faq.question: Is the worktree creation automatic?
faq.answer: Yes, if auto_worktree is enabled in settings - otherwise you'll need to create it manually.

faq.question: How does this integrate with CI/CD?
faq.answer: GHE includes monitoring workflows that track claimed issues and can trigger appropriate CI pipelines.
